hedline.hl1: When the First Stop Is the E.R.

abstract.p: Dr Edward J Volpintesta letter on Oct 25 article holds health maintenance organizations impose too much red tape on primary care doctors; drawing

block.p: Re ''Emergency Room, to Many, Remains the Doctor's Office'' (front page, Oct. 25):

Health maintenance organizations beleaguer doctors with red tape. Dealing with the interruptions caused by getting clearances for consultations and referrals wears down primary care doctors, wastes their time, demoralizes them and makes them less productive.
Re ''Emergency Room, to Many, Remains the Doctor's Office'' (front page, Oct. 25):

Health maintenance organizations beleaguer doctors with red tape. Dealing with the interruptions caused by getting clearances for consultations and referrals wears down primary care doctors, wastes their time, demoralizes them and makes them less productive.
Taking care of sick patients is challenge enough, but having to deal with the interruptions imposed on them by H.M.O.'s is getting to be too much for most primary care doctors.
Until the red tape disappears, patients will increasingly bring their primary care problems to the emergency room.
EDWARD J. VOLPINTESTA, M.D. Bethel, Conn., Oct. 25, 2000
